comment:
Let's cite Savely Tartakover here: "old nad bad" is
his short comment in the classic "Die hypermoderne Schachpartie" (1925)
A rare continuation. The usual moves order here is:

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 Bc5 3. Nf3 d6 4. c3 f5 5. fxe5 dxe5 6. d4 exd4 7. Bc4 fxe4
comment:
7... Nc6 is the more usual continuation here
but it does not equalize the black game at all as the following gem of a game
demonstrates:

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 Bc5 3. Nf3 d6 4. c3 f5 5. fxe5 dxe5 6. d4 exd4 7. Bc4 fxe4 8. Ne5
comment:
The critical point of the
game. White has two continuations here: 8.Ng5 or 8. Ne5. Ng5 looks stronger at
first glance since in it the knight covers the important h4-d8 diagonal but
black can get acceptable play in it, e.g.:

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 Bc5 3. Nf3 d6 4. c3 f5 5. fxe5 dxe5 6. d4 exd4 7. Bc4 fxe4 8. Ne5 Qh4+
1. e4 e5 2. f4 Bc5 3. Nf3 d6 4. c3 f5 5. fxe5 dxe5 6. d4 exd4 7. Bc4 fxe4 8. Ne5 Qh4+ 9. g3 Qf6 10. cxd4 Bb4+ 11. Nc3 Ne7 12. Rf1
comment: The moves order has to be precise or else black can get counterchances:

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 Bc5 3. Nf3 d6 4. c3 f5 5. fxe5 dxe5 6. d4 exd4 7. Bc4 fxe4 8. Ne5 Qh4+ 9. g3 Qf6 10. cxd4 Bb4+ 11. Nc3 Ne7 12. Rf1 Bf5 13. Qb3 Nec6
comment: to make place at e7 for a king retreat

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 Bc5 3. Nf3 d6 4. c3 f5 5. fxe5 dxe5 6. d4 exd4 7. Bc4 fxe4 8. Ne5 Qh4+ 9. g3 Qf6 10. cxd4 Bb4+ 11. Nc3 Ne7 12. Rf1 Bf5 13. Qb3 Nec6 14. Bf7+ Ke7
comment: all other king retreats lose immediately:

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 Bc5 3. Nf3 d6 4. c3 f5 5. fxe5 dxe5 6. d4 exd4 7. Bc4 fxe4 8. Ne5 Qh4+ 9. g3 Qf6 10. cxd4 Bb4+ 11. Nc3 Ne7 12. Rf1 Bf5 13. Qb3 Nec6 14. Bf7+ Ke7 15. Bd5
1. e4 e5 2. f4 Bc5 3. Nf3 d6 4. c3 f5 5. fxe5 dxe5 6. d4 exd4 7. Bc4 fxe4 8. Ne5 Qh4+ 9. g3 Qf6 10. cxd4 Bb4+ 11. Nc3 Ne7 12. Rf1 Bf5 13. Qb3 Nec6 14. Bf7+ Ke7 15. Bd5 a5 16. Be3 a4 17. Qc4 g6
comment: ? This loses per force. Better chances offered 17...Bxc3:

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 Bc5 3. Nf3 d6 4. c3 f5 5. fxe5 dxe5 6. d4 exd4 7. Bc4 fxe4 8. Ne5 Qh4+ 9. g3 Qf6 10. cxd4 Bb4+ 11. Nc3 Ne7 12. Rf1 Bf5 13. Qb3 Nec6 14. Bf7+ Ke7 15. Bd5 a5 16. Be3 a4 17. Qc4 g6 18. O-O-O
comment:
! Probably it was this move that black did not expect. The pawn win at e4 is
weaker:

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 Bc5 3. Nf3 d6 4. c3 f5 5. fxe5 dxe5 6. d4 exd4 7. Bc4 fxe4 8. Ne5 Qh4+ 9. g3 Qf6 10. cxd4 Bb4+ 11. Nc3 Ne7 12. Rf1 Bf5 13. Qb3 Nec6 14. Bf7+ Ke7 15. Bd5 a5 16. Be3 a4 17. Qc4 g6 18. O-O-O Bxc3 19. Qxc3 Qd6
comment: ? the best chance here was 19...a3, as shown by the following continuation:

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 Bc5 3. Nf3 d6 4. c3 f5 5. fxe5 dxe5 6. d4 exd4 7. Bc4 fxe4 8. Ne5 Qh4+ 9. g3 Qf6 10. cxd4 Bb4+ 11. Nc3 Ne7 12. Rf1 Bf5 13. Qb3 Nec6 14. Bf7+ Ke7 15. Bd5 a5 16. Be3 a4 17. Qc4 g6 18. O-O-O Bxc3 19. Qxc3 Qd6 20. Bg5+ Ke8 21. Bf7+ Kf8 22. g4 Nd7
comment:
? I do not understand that move.
Black had much better continuations here, e.g.:

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 Bc5 3. Nf3 d6 4. c3 f5 5. fxe5 dxe5 6. d4 exd4 7. Bc4 fxe4 8. Ne5 Qh4+ 9. g3 Qf6 10. cxd4 Bb4+ 11. Nc3 Ne7 12. Rf1 Bf5 13. Qb3 Nec6 14. Bf7+ Ke7 15. Bd5 a5 16. Be3 a4 17. Qc4 g6 18. O-O-O Bxc3 19. Qxc3 Qd6 20. Bg5+ Ke8 21. Bf7+ Kf8 22. g4 Nd7 23. gxf5 Ndxe5 24. dxe5 Qxe5 25. Qxe5 Nxe5
comment: after the queens are exchanged there is even not a vague hope for black

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 Bc5 3. Nf3 d6 4. c3 f5 5. fxe5 dxe5 6. d4 exd4 7. Bc4 fxe4 8. Ne5 Qh4+ 9. g3 Qf6 10. cxd4 Bb4+ 11. Nc3 Ne7 12. Rf1 Bf5 13. Qb3 Nec6 14. Bf7+ Ke7 15. Bd5 a5 16. Be3 a4 17. Qc4 g6 18. O-O-O Bxc3 19. Qxc3 Qd6 20. Bg5+ Ke8 21. Bf7+ Kf8 22. g4 Nd7 23. gxf5 Ndxe5 24. dxe5 Qxe5 25. Qxe5 Nxe5 26. fxg6 Nf3 27. Rd7
